messageBody:
On 3/24/06, amine achergui <amine.achergui@...> wrote:
> Hi folks,
> Is there any test pattern to test a recursive method ( in my case,
> the method's body calls collaborators thus in the test method i use mocks).
> Is there any pattern or recipe to solve this?
> Thx.
> Amine

Perhaps J.B. has a specific recipe for this. I do have his book, but
it's at work and I'm at home right now.

Anyway, to a certain extent, JUnit doesn't actually care how the
method that it calls does it's job. If you are testing
Library.recursiveMethod() and it returns a result, then just test the
result. If there are some standard "easy" results then start by
getting those to work right.

A more concrete example perhaps: Take the factorial calculation. The
input values of zero and one give known, defined, values. So when
writing a version of factorial, I'd start with those and ensure that
they worked before progressing on to the calculated values.

assertEquals(0, Factorial.calculate(0));

and

assertEquals(1, Factorial.calculate(1));

Then, when those tests pass, move onto the input values that you know
will force recursive calculations.

Using JUnit isn't only about testing assertions, although that's
wonderful enough, it's also about guiding you to think about testing
your code and making it provably correct before/during/after you write
it.

JUnit could care less about how you implement your method, but *you*
need to care plenty about whether it's testable.

Simon
